intro: Matelea acuminata, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family, which includes milkweeds and other flowering plants with showy blooms. The plant is characterized by its large, white, fragrant flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators like moths. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are cylindrical and often branched. Matelea acuminata is typically found in dry, rocky habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid environments.
